awd_titl_txt: EAGER:   Repository Cross-Linking for Open Archiving and Sharing of Scientific Data and Articles
awd_abstract_narration:
The open availability and wide accessibility of scientific articles, data sets, and other digital resources is becoming the norm for 21st century science. Growing numbers of repositories of scientific resources enable researchers to discover, understand, and build upon previous work at greater scales than was previously possible. Many interrelationships exist between research articles, data, software, and other services used to produce scientific findings. Repositories for these resources, however, typically only supporting one particular kind of resource, or at most will support a couple of resource types, such as data and software. This has led to the siloing of information in a vast number of repositories. Producers and users of scientific resources would benefit from repositories with different specializations and user communities working together at a technical and process level to provide greater services than any one repository can provide. Through developing common workflows and information exchange protocols, this project will demonstrate how repository interconnections can be built in ways that establish connections between related resources (e.g. data, software, services, etc.). 

This project will provide a model for how multiple repositories of diverse resources can exchange
and connect related information via complementary workflows and metadata sharing. The project
will consider two different cases: 1) connecting resources that are already hosted by repositories,
and 2) connecting resources as they are newly deposited into repositories. These are common
cases among data, articles, and software repositories. Case #1 looks backward in time, and
case #2 looks forward in time. This project will produce a pilot implementation of repository cross-linking, using two repositories provided and managed by the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) / National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) as the development bed: 1) the OpenSky repository, which hosts and provides access to the record of scholarship produced by UCAR and NCAR staff, and is the platform for publishing the NCAR Technical Notes series, and 2) is the Earth System Grid (ESG), which is a NCAR-hosted infrastructure for the distribution and access of climate models, data, and software. Building connections between repositories increases public access to geosciences information and data by increasing the visibility of data and information across previously unconnected systems, thereby increasing discoverability, and by increasing the utility of data through explicitly linking data to important documentation. Theproject outcomes will be shared and explored with the relevant stakeholders communities through a workshop, and with the communities brought together through EarthCube, namely, the geosciences, informatics experts, scientific publishers, and data repositories.

por.por_cntn:
This project, “EAGER: Repository Cross-Linking for Open Archiving and Sharing of Scientific Data and Articles,” investigated how repositories of related digital scientific resources can interact. The project developed a demonstration of how repository interconnections can be built between related resources (e.g. data, software, services, and publications). This pilot implementation uses repositories provided and managed by the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) as the development testbed, namely the NCAR Library’s OpenSky repository and the Earth System Grid (ESG), which is operated by NCAR’s Computational and Information Systems Lab. Our approach has been to develop cross-links between these two systems that allow researchers who deposit resources in one system to initiate the deposit of related resources in the other. Links between the related resources held in the two separate systems are being exchanged and made visible in the respective systems.

The intellectual merits of the project relate to the specific objectives of this EAGER project: to identify, scope, test, and deploy repository features that allow links between related resources to be created, exchanged, and maintained over time with low technical hurdles and minimal repository curator effort. The focus of the activities of this project have been: 1) specifying use cases and stakeholders, 2) developing technical requirements for these use cases and stakeholders, 3) developing system functionalities that meet the use case and stakeholder requirements, and 4) conducting a workshop to present our project results and engender broader discussion around the project topics

The outcome of this project is a model for the design of information exchange between open access repositories. This model includes a set of technical requirements, including metadata structures for documenting relationships, protocols for cross-repository notifications and metadata exchanges, and displays that make the relationships understandable to resource users. We leveraged the SHARE Notify service as a third-party notification tool to enable our repositories to interact. SHARE Notify provides a service for creating notifications of research publication “events.” Our interest in using SHARE Notify is to send notifications of relationship "events" between our repositories. For example, if article "A" hosted in the OpenSky repository is published based on data set "B" hosted by the Earth System Grid, OpenSky can post a notification via SHARE Notify. The ESG can then find that notification by watching OpenSky’s SHARE feed. The SHARE Notify service is appealing for our project because it eliminates the need for every repository to directly connect to every other repository. Although this EAGER project focuses on the connections between OpenSky and ESG, both systems will be able to send notification feeds about relations through SHARE Notify to any other repository. SHARE Notify thus provides a scalable means of distributing information to numerous potential partners. The SHARE Notify metadata feeds are also open to machine ingest and processing by other parties, so the feeds our project creates can be gathered into any additional service that is aggregating information about relationships between repository resources.

The project’s broader impacts relate to the “Data and Publication Linking Workshop” held in January of 2016. The workshop brought together a small group of leaders and experts in the scholarly publishing and curation communities. A workshop report has been published to disseminate the key outcomes.
